newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia nabs millions in "federal" drug money.
newsitem.headline: Colombia nabs millions in "federal" drug money.

text.p: Nearly $5 million in suspected drug money was seized in Colombia's southwest city of Cali Tuesday, most of it $100 and $50 bills still sealed in wrappers from the U.S. Federal Reserve, authorities said.

National Police chief Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano said the cash was discovered in a house believed to belong to Helmer "El Pacho" Herrera, the No. 4 man in the Cali drug cartel who surrendered to police last September.

Herrera's personal fortune has been estimated by Colombia's leading news magazine, Semana, at $11 billion and he is the target of an outstanding extradition request made by U.S. Attorney General Janet Reno last summer.

Serrano told Reuters a sophisticated radio communications network, valued at about $1 million and complete with scanners to monitor police and military radio frequencies, was also discovered in one of six raids on suspected cartel properties in and around Cali.
The raids marked a major setback for what U.S. authorities have described as the world's biggest-ever criminal drug trafficking organisation, Serrano said.

"This is biggest hit on the Cali cartel since its maximum leaders were arrested in 1995," he said. Brothers Gilberto and Miguel Rodriguez Orejulea, the cartel's masterminds, were arrested in June and August of 1995.

A senior police official initially said $5.5 million had been seized in the raid on the house in the La Vega district of Cali where the suspected cocaine cash was stashed. But Serrano said the loot totalled $4.8 million and that most of it was in packets of $1,000, neatly piled away in original wrappers from a U.S. Federal Reserve bank.
Serrano, who spoke in a brief telephone interview with Reuters from Cali, was unable to specify which Federal Reserve bank the money had come from.
